Question: Which of the following states has the highest fertility rate in India according to the 2011 census?
Solution:
The correct answer is Bihar.
Key Points
  • According to the 2011 census in India, the state with the highest fertility rate was Bihar, with a total fertility rate of 3.4.
  • Population: Bihar is the third most populous state in India with a population of 104,099,452.
    • It accounts for 8.58% of India's population.
  • Gender Ratio: The sex ratio in Bihar has improved marginally from 919 in 2001 to 918 in 2011.
    • However, the state still has one of the lowest gender ratios in India.
  • Literacy Rate: The literacy rate in Bihar has improved significantly from 47.0% in 2001 to 61.8% in 2011.
    • However, it is still lower than the national average of 74.04%.
  • Rural-Urban Divide: Bihar is predominantly a rural state with 89.7% of its population residing in rural areas.
    • The state has a low urbanization rate of 10.3%.
  • Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes: The Scheduled Castes (SC) and Scheduled Tribes (ST) together constitute 15.6% of Bihar's population.
    • The literacy rate among SCs is 52.5% and among STs is 47.0%.
Additional Information
  • Census of India
    • Census 2011 was the 15th Census of India and the 7th Census after independence.
    • 8 Census has been conducted prior to independence.
    • Census is conducted every 10 years in India.
    • The first Census in India was conducted in the year 1872.

Question:
With the 2022 amendments to the Indian Constitution, which of the following communities have been granted the Scheduled Tribes status by the Government of India?
A. Narikoravan community
B. Hattee community
C. Kadu Kuruba community
D. Kapu community
Solution:
The correct answer is A, B and C onlyKey Points:
  • In 2022, the Lok Sabha received the Constitution (Scheduled Tribes) Order (Second Amendment) Bill.
  • Arjun Munda introduced it in the Lok Sabha.
  • The Constitution (Scheduled Tribes) Order, 1950, as it relates to Tamil Nadu, is to be amended by the bill.
  • In states and union territories, the Order identifies the tribal groups that are considered to be Scheduled Tribes.
  • After this Bill is approved, the Gond group will be moved from the list of SCs to the list of STs, and the Dhuria, Nayak, Ojha, Pathari, and Rajgond will be added to the list of STs in Uttar Pradesh in the four districts of Sant Kabir Nagar, Kushinagar, Chandauli, and Bhadohi.
  • The Narikoravan and Kurivikkaran communities are listed among the Scheduled Tribes in the Bill in Tamil Nadu.
  • The Bill will amend the Constitution (Scheduled Tribes) Order, 1950, for inclusion of the Hattee community of the Trans Giri area of the Sirmour district of Himachal Pradesh in the list of Scheduled Tribes.
  • In the Schedule to the Constitution (Scheduled Tribes) Order, 1950, in PART VI.—Karnataka added Kadu Kuruba, Betta-Kuruba.

Question: In 1962, who published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates could move, later called 'sea floor spreading'?
Solution:
The correct answer is Harry Hammond Hess.
Key Points
  • In 1962, Harry Hammond Hess, a geologist and Navy officer, published 'The History of Ocean Basins', which outlined the theory of how tectonic plates could move, later called 'sea floor spreading'.
  • Hess proposed that new ocean crust was being continuously formed at mid-ocean ridges, where magma rises from the mantle and solidifies, pushing older crust away from the ridge and eventually causing it to subduct or be destroyed at deep-sea trenches.
  • This theory, which became known as plate tectonics, revolutionized the field of geology and helped explain a wide range of geological phenomena, from the distribution of earthquakes and volcanoes to the formation of mountains and the evolution of life on Earth.
Additional Information
  • Plate Tectonic Theory:
    • Plate tectonic theory describes the movement of the Earth's lithosphere, which is composed of several large and many smaller plates, driven by the convective motion of the mantle.
    • These plates move relative to one another, resulting in the formation of new crust at mid-ocean ridges and the destruction of old crust at subduction zones.
    • This movement is responsible for a wide range of geological phenomena, including the distribution of earthquakes and volcanoes, the formation of mountain ranges, and the evolution of continents.
    • For example, the collision of the Indian and Eurasian plates formed the Himalayas, and the separation of the African and South American plates created the Atlantic Ocean.
    • The theory also explains the distribution of fossils, as species separated by the movement of plates evolved differently.

Question: Identify a class of compounds that has a functional group –OH.
Solution:
The correct option is Alcohol.
Key Points:
  • The Hydroxyl (-OH) functional group attached to the aliphatic carbon atom of the alkyl group forms alcohols.
  • The general formula for alcohol is R-OH, where R is the alkyl group and -OH is the hydroxyl group.
  • There are three types of alcohol: primary, secondary, and tertiary.
  • Primary alcohols are those in which the carbon atom attached to the OH group is connected with one alkyl group (RCH2-OH).
  • Secondary alcohols are those in which the carbon atom attached to the OH group is connected with two alkyl groups (R2CH-OH).
  • Tertiary alcohols are those in which the carbon atom attached to the OH group is connected with three alkyl groups (R3C-OH).
  • The general name for alcohol is 'alkyl alcohol', Ex: methyl alcohol, ethyl alcohol, etc.
  • The IUPAC name of alcohols is written using the suffix 'ol' as an alkanol, Ex: methanol, ethanol, etc.
Additional Information: Acids
  • Acids are the compounds containing the carboxylic (COOH)group.
  • It has the general formulaR-COOH.
Phenols
  • Phenols are compounds containing OH groups attached to a benzene ring.
  • The general formula of phenol is C6H5-OH.
Aldehydes
  • Aldehydes are the compound containing the -CHO (aldehyde) functional group.
  • The general formula for aldehydes is R-CHO.
Ethers
  • Ethers are compounds containing two alkyl groups attached with one oxygen centrally.
  • It has general formula R-O-R.

Question:
Match the columns.
MineralReserves region
(a)Bauxite(i)Lohardaga
(b)Mica(ii)Bhilwara
(c)Coal(iii)Jhunjhunu
(d)Copper(iv)Jharia
OP1: A - IV, B - III, C - I, D - II
OP2: A - I, B - II, C - IV, D - III
OP3: A - II, B - III, C - IV, D - I
OP4: A - II, B - I, C - III, D - IV
Solution:
Correct Answer A - I, B - II, C - IV, D - III
Key PointsBauxite:
  • Bauxite is the ore that is used in the manufacturing of aluminum.
  • Bauxite is found mainly in tertiary deposits and is associated with laterite rocks occurring extensively either on the plateau or hill ranges of peninsular India and also in the coastal tracts of the country.
  • Odisha happens to be the largest producer of Bauxite.
  • Kalahandi and Sambalpur are the leading producers.
  • The other two areas which have been increasing their production are Bolangir and Koraput.
  • The peatlands of Jharkhand in Lohardaga have rich deposits.
  • Gujarat, Chhattisgarh, Madhya Pradesh, and Maharashtra are other major producers.
  • Bhavnagar and Jamnagar in Gujarat have major deposits.
  • Chhattisgarh has bauxite deposits in the Amarkantak plateau while the Katni-Jabalpur area and Balaghat in M.P. have important deposits of bauxite.
  • Kolaba, Thane, Ratnagiri, Satara, Pune, and Kolhapur in Maharashtra are important producers.
  • Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, and Goa are minor producers of bauxite.
Copper
  • Copper deposits are largely concentrated in the Singhbhum district of Jharkhand, Balaghat district of Madhya Pradesh, and Jhunjhunu and Alwar districts of Rajasthan.
Mica:
  • Hazaribagh plateau of Jharkhand and Nellore district of Andhra Pradesh has deposits of high-grade mica.
  • Jaipur to Bhilwara and areas around Udaipur are the major mica-bearing regions of Rajasthan.
  • Other mica-bearing regions are the Mysore and Hasan districts of Karnataka; Coimbatore, Tiruchirapalli, Madurai, and Kanniyakumari of Tamil Nadu; Alleppey of Kerala; Ratnagiri of Maharashtra; Purulia and Bankura of West Bengal.
Jharia:
  • Jharia coalfields are in Jharkhand’s Dhanbad district and span over 450 square kilometres.
  • It is one of the oldest and richest coal fields of India and has been recognized as the storehouse of the best metallurgical coal in the country.
  • On account of the growing needs of the steel industry, a thrust had to be given on the systematic exploitation of coking coal reserves in Jharia Coalfield.
  • Coal Mines in Jharkhand:
    • Jharia, Dhanbad, Bokaro, Jayanti, Godda, Giridih (Karbhari Coal Field), Ramgarh, Karanpura, Daltonganj.

Question: What was the distance (around in km) covered by the first-ever train between Bombay and Thane in 1853?
Solution:
Correct Answer 34
Key Points:First passenger train:
  • The first passenger train in India started from Mumbai (Bori Bunder) to Thane.
  • It operated on 16 April 1853.
  • It consisted of fourteen carriages and was operated by three steam locomotives.
  • The three steam locomotives were namely Sahib, Sultan, and Sindh.
  • The train ran for 34 km with 400 people.
  • India's first passenger train was operated by Great Indian Peninsula Railway.
  • The Great Indian Peninsula Railway was founded on 1st August 1849.

Question: Which of the following books was written by the Roman writer Pliny the elder?
Solution:
The correct answer is Natural History.
Key Points:
  • Natural History was written by the Roman writer Pliny the Elder in 77 AD, who wrote in this book that Rome was wasting its gold reserves by trading with India.
    • Pliny the Elder wrote a book titled "The Natural History", often known as Naturalis Historia.
    • Natural History gathers data from various ancient authors and is the largest single work to have survived from the Roman Empire to the present.
    • Despite the work's title, Pliny himself characterizes his subject matter as "the natural world, or life," rather than what is currently recognized as natural history.
    • Its scope is encyclopedic, although its organization differs from that of a contemporary encyclopedia.
    • It was Pliny's final publication and the only one of his writings to have survived.
Additional Information:
  • Periplus of the Erythraean Sea:
    • ​The Periplus of the Erythraean Sea, also known by its Latin name, the Periplus Maris Erythraei, is a Greco-Roman periplus that describes trade and navigation opportunities from Roman Egyptian ports along the Red Sea coast, such as Berenice Troglodytica, as well as those along the Horn of Africa, the Arabian Sea, the Persian Gulf, and the Indian Ocean, including the modern-day Sindh region of Pakistan and the southwest of India.
  • Indica:
    • ​The Greek author Megasthenes' account of Mauryan India is titled Indika.
    • Although the original work is now lost, succeeding Greek and Latin writings still have some of its parts.
  • Geographica:
    • ​The Geographica, or Geography, is a collection of 17 Greek-language "books" that serves as an encyclopaedia of geographic information.
    • It is credited to Strabo, a learned Roman citizen of Greek heritage.

Question: Which law was studied in the year 1787, in which it was said that the volume of a gas increases with its absolute temperature and if its absolute temperature decreases, then its volume will decrease?
Solution:
The correct answer is Charles's law
Key Points:
  • Avogadro's law combines the conclusions of Dalton’s atomic theory and Gay Lussac’s law of combining volumes.
  • It states that equal volumes of all gases under the same conditions of temperature and pressure contain equal number of molecules.
  • Mathematically it can be written as V ∝ n, where n is the number of moles of the gas.
  • The number of molecules in one mole of a gas is 6.022 x 1023and is known as the Avogadro constant.
  • Gay Lussac’s Law:
    • At constant volume, pressure of a fixed amount of a gas varies directly with the temperature.
    • Mathematically, \({p \over T} = Constant = k_3\).
  • Charles’ Law:
    • At constant pressure, the volume of a fixed mass of a gas is directly proportional to its absolute temperature.
    • Mathematically, \({V \over T} = Constant = k_2\).
  • Boyle’s Law:
    • At constant temperature, the pressure of a fixed amount of gas varies inversely with its volume.
    • Mathematically, \(p ∝ {1 \over V}\).

Question: In India, which of the following bills CANNOT be introduced in the Rajya Sabha?
OP1: Both constitutional amendment and ordinary bills
Solution:
The correct answer is Money Bill.
Key Points:
  • Money Bill can NOT be first introduced in Rajya Sabha.
  • Article 110 of the Constitution deals with Money Bills.
  • A Bill is said to be a Money Bill if it only contains provisions related to
    • taxation
    • borrowing of money by the government
    • expenditure from or receipt to the Consolidated Fund of India.
  • A money Bill can be introduced only in Lok Sabha with prior approval from the president.
  • How money bill is passed-
    • A Money Bill may only be introduced in Lok Sabha, on the recommendation of the President. It must be passed in Lok Sabha by a simple majority of all members present and voting.
    • Following this, it may be sent to the Rajya Sabha for its recommendations, which Lok Sabha may reject if it chooses to.
    • If such recommendations are not given within 14 days, it will be deemed to be passed by Parliament.

Question: Which Article of the Constitution of India empowers a high court to issue a writ?
Solution:
The correct answer is Article 226.Key Points:
  • The High Court has the jurisdiction under Article 226 to issue directions, orders or writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.
  • A High Court is empowered to issue directions, orders, or writs for the enforcement of a Fundamental Right and for any other purpose those include:
    • Habeas corpus
    • Mandamus
    • Prohibition
    • Quo warranto
    • Certiorari.
  • The phrase ‘for any other purpose’ refers to the enforcement of an ordinary legal right.
  • The high court can issue writs to any person, authority and government not only within its territorial jurisdiction but also outside its territorial jurisdiction if the cause of action arises within its territorial jurisdiction.
Additional Information:
Description of 5 writs:
WritDescription
Habeas corpusA writ of habeas corpus is used to bring a prisoner or other detainee before the court to determine if the person's imprisonment or detention is lawful.
MandamusIt is a judicial writ issued as a command to an inferior court or ordering a person to perform a public or statutory duty.
ProhibitionThis writ is often issued by a superior court to the lower court directing it not to proceed with a case that does not fall under its jurisdiction.
Quo warrantoIt a writ or legal action requiring a person to show by what warrant an office or franchise is held, claimed, or exercised.
CertiorariA type of writ, by which an appellate court decides to review a case at its discretion.

Question: In which year was the Doppler effect discovered by Austrian scientist Christian Doppler, that describes the change in frequency of any kind of sound or light wave produced by a moving source with respect to an observer?
Solution:
Correct Answer 1842
Key Points:
  • Doppler Effect was first described by Christian Doppler, an Austrian physicist, who did it in 1842.
Doppler effect:
  • The Doppler Effect affects both light and sound.
  • If the source or the observer or both move with respect to the medium, then the frequency observed may be different from the frequency of the source.
  • This apparent change in the frequency of the wave due to the motion of the source or the observer is called the Doppler Effect.
  • The apparent frequency of the sound experienced by the observer, when the observer is stationary and the source is moving is \({f}'=\left( \frac{v}{v\pm {{v}_{S}}} \right)f\)
  • The apparent frequency of the sound experienced by the observer, when the source is stationary and the observer is moving is ​​\({f}'=\left( \frac{v\pm {{v}_{O}}}{v} \right)f\)
  • Where,
    ⇒ v = speed of sound in the medium,
    ⇒ f’ = apparent frequency,
    ⇒ f = natural frequency
    ⇒ vs & vo= speed of the source & observer respectively
  • Doppler effect in light is symmetric because light waves are electromagnetic (do not require medium) while in Sound it is asymmetric.

Question: Which Article of the Constitution of India lays down that an Indian citizen has the right to use any restaurant, road or public place?
Solution:
The correct answer is 15(2).
Key Points:
  • Article 15: This Article guarantees the prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth by the State. It also ensures equality in educational opportunities in India.
  • Article 15(1) prohibits the State to discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, or any of them.
  • Article 15 (2) prohibits citizens on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth, or any of them, be subject to any disability, liability, restriction, or condition with regard to
    • access to shops, public restaurants, hotels, and palaces of public entertainment;
    • or the use of wells, tanks, bathing ghats, roads, and places of public resort maintained wholly or partly out of State funds or dedicated to the use of the general public
  • Article 15(3) empowered the state to make special provisions for the welfare of women and children
  • ARTICLE 15 (4): It enabled the government to make special provisions for the advancement of backward classes including the Scheduled Castes (SCs) and Scheduled Tribes (STs). It also ensures the reservation in educational institutes for the SCs and the STs.
Additional Information:
  • Article 14: The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India, on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
  • Article 16: There shall be equality of opportunity for all citizens in matters relating to employment or appointment to any office under the State.
  • Article 17: Abolition of untouchability.
  • Article 18: Abolition of all titles except military and academic titles.
Important Points:
  • Fundamental rights are the rights that are essential for the survival of people with dignity.
  • The Indian Constitution accommodates fundamental rights that are Justiciable subject to reasonable restrictions.
There are six fundamental rights namely
  1. Right to Equality (Article 14-18)
  2. Right to freedom (Article 19-22)
  3. Right against exploitation (Article 23 and 24)
  4. Right to freedom of religion (Article 25-28)
  5. Cultural and educational rights (Article 29 and 30)
  6. Rights to constitutional remedies (Article 32)

Question: Which of the following is an indirect tax?
Solution:
The correct answer is Goods and services tax
Key Points
  • Indirect tax -
    • The tax which is not taken directly from the public but reaches the government indirectly is called indirect tax.
    • The tax levied by the state on consumption, import, export, and production, etc. is an indirect tax.
    • Excise Duty was a type of Indirect Tax which was imposed on all production or manufacturing of goods.
  • Excise duty has been replaced by the Goods and Services Tax(GST) w.e.f. 1 July 2017.
    • GST subsumed many central and state indirect taxes.
    • It is a destination-based tax.
  • Following indirect taxes were subsumed under GST:
    • Taxes collected by Centre: Central Excise Duty, Duties of Excise, Additional Duties of Excise, Additional Duties of Customs, Special Additional Duty of Customs, Service Tax and Central Surcharges and Cesses so far as they relate to supply of goods and services.
    • Taxes collected by State: State VAT, Central Sales Tax, Luxury Tax, Entry Tax, Entertainment and Amusement Tax, Taxes on advertisements, Purchase Tax, Taxes on lotteries, Betting and Gambling, State Surcharges and Cesses so far as they relate to supply of goods and services.
  • Some goods are beyond the scope of GST.
    • Petroleum, High-speed diesel, Petrol, Natural gas, Aviation fuel and Liquor. Export Duty, Basic Customs Duty, Toll Tax, Stamp Duty, Property Tax, Road & Passenger Tax, Electricity Duty were not subsumed under GST.

Question: In India, which of the following is NOT an objective of the National Manufacturing Policy?

OP2: To double the exports of manufacturing goods by 2022.
OP3: To increase the rate of job creation so as to create 100 million additional jobs by 2022
OP4: To enhance global competitiveness, domestic value addition, technological depth and environmental sustainability of growth.

  • The National Manufacturing Policy aims to create 100 million additional jobs in the next decade.
  • The draft policy envisages the establishment of National Investment and Manufacturing Zones (NIMZ) equipped with world-class infrastructure.
  • Each National Investment and Manufacturing Zones will have 5,000 hectares.

Question: What is the name of the scheme launched in 2021 for students to attain foundational literacy and numeracy up to class 3?
Solution:
Correct Answer NIPUN Bharat
National Education Policy (NEP) 2020 gives the highest priority to the universal acquisition of foundational literacy and numeracy skills at the primary level. Further, it states that the rest of this Policy will be largely irrelevant for a large portion of our students if this most basic learning, i.e., reading, writing, and arithmetic at the foundational level is not first achieved.
Key Points:
  • Recognizing the crucial role of Foundational skills in national development, a National Foundational Literacy and Numeracy Mission named ‘National Initiative for Proficiency in Reading with Understanding and Numeracy - NIPUN Bharat’ was launched on 5th July 2021.
  • The purpose is to ensure that every child in the country necessarily attains foundational literacy and numeracy in Grade 3 by 2026-27.
  • Ministry of Education has launched a National Initiative for Proficiency in Reading with Understanding and Numeracy (NIPUN Bharat), for ensuring that every child in the country necessarily attains foundational literacy and numeracy (FLN).
  • The mission will focus on children of age groups of 3 to 9 years including preschool to Grade 3.
  • The children who are in Classes 4 and 5 and have not attained the foundational skills will be provided individual teacher guidance and support, peer support, and age-appropriate and supplementary graded learning materials to acquire the necessary competencies.
  • The goals and objectives of the mission are required to be achieved by all Govt., Govt. Aided and Private Schools so that universal acquisition of FLN skills can be achieved by 2026-27.
Thus, it is concluded that the NIPUN BHARAT represents a National Initiative taken by the Ministry of Education in 2021 to ensure that every child in the country attains Foundational literacy and Numeracy.
Additional Information: NISHTHA 2.0​
  • National Initiative for School Heads' and Teachers' Holistic Advancement (NISHTHA)
  • It is an initiative of the Department of School Education and Literacy, Ministry of Education under the Centrally Sponsored Scheme of Samagra Shiksha during 2019-20.
  • It is a capacity-building program for Improving the Quality of School Education through Integrated Teacher Training.
  • The basic objective of the program is to motivate and equip teachers to foster critical thinking in students.
  • The initiative is the first of its kind wherein standardized training modules are developed at the national level for all States and UTs.
  • Expected Outcomes:
    • Improvement in learning outcomes of the students.
    • Creation of an enabling and enriching inclusive classroom environment.
    • Creation of a healthy and safe school environment.
    • Integration of ICT in teaching-learning and assessment.
Structured Assessment for Analyzing Learning (SAFAL):
  • One of the key focuses of the National Education Policy, 2020 is skill-based and competency-based assessment, and of NIPUN Bharat.
  • For improving the achievement of student learning outcomes in the foundational years, the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) is planning to introduce a competency-based assessment to assess student learning outcomes on key competencies.
  • The proposed name of the assessment is Structured Assessment for Analyzing Learning (SAFAL).
  • The assessment would be focused on the assessment of core competencies.
  • SAFAL results would provide diagnostic data and insights to each school for promoting the development of students.
Purposes:
  1. Nudge system toward competency-based learning
  2. Measure school performance on major competencies
  3. Identify areas of academic intervention for support/ management

Question: Zafar khan was a famous General of which of the following rulers of the Delhi Sultanate?
Solution:
The correct answer is Alauddin Khilji
Key PointsZafar Khan
  • He was the general of Sultan Allauddin Khilji who defeated Duwa Khan, a Mongol invader in 1297.
  • During the Mongol invasion of 1299 by Kutlugh Khwaja, Zafar Khan was the general of the right wing of the army.
  • He was cut off by an ambush and was killed. But the Mongols were still repealed by Allauddin's army.
  • He held charge of Multan, Samana, and Sivistan at various times during Alauddin's reign.
  • Associated with Alauddin since the latter days as a governor of Kara, Zafar Khan led a major division of Alauddin's army from Kara to Delhi after Alauddin assassinated his predecessor Jalaluddin in 1296.
  • Along with Alauddin's brother Ulugh Khan, he led the army that invaded Multan to eliminate the surviving members of Jalaluddin's family.
  • He along with Ulugh Khan probably led the Delhi army that inflicted a crushing defeat on the Chagatai Mongol invaders at Jaran Manjur in 1298.
Additional InformationAla-ud-din Khilji (1296-1316 A.D.)
  • In 1296 A.D. Ala-ud-din Khilji succeeded Jalal-ud-din Firoz Khilji and ascended the throne.
  • Ala-ud-din Khilji Invasions in the North- captured Ranthambore and killed Hamir Deva its ruler and also captured Malwa, Chittor, Dhar, Mandu, Ujjain, Marwar, Chanderi, and Jalor.
  • Ala-ud-din Khilji Invasions in the South - was the first Sultan who attacked South India and sent General Malik Kafur against the rulers of the south. Prataprudra-II of Warangal, Ramachandra Deva, the Yadava king of Devagiri, and Vira Ballala-III the Hoysala king were defeated.
  • The domestic Policies of Alauddin Khilji Ala-ud-din followed -the Divine Right Theory of Kingship, introduced four ordinances to prevent repeated revolts; impounded pious grants and free grants of lands; restructured the spy system; banned social parties and wine; introduced a permanent standing army; started the system of branding of horses and a descriptive roster of individual soldiers to inhibit corruption; fixed the prices of necessary commodities which were below the normal market rates; strictly prohibited black marketing. Revenue was collected in cash and not in kind; followed discriminatory policies towards the Hindus and imposed the Jizya, a grazing tax, and a house tax on the Hindu community.
  • He was the first to bring the standing army system.
  • He constructed Alai Darwaza, the Palace of a thousand pillars and the Fort of Siri.
Iltutmish:
  • He was the third ruler of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • Born to a slave, he rose to power and became the ruler of Delhi.
  • Since Iltutmish was the 1st Muslim sultan to establish Delhi as an imperial capital, he was regarded as the genuine founder of the Delhi Sultanate.
  • He was also the Khalifa’s first recognition of an Indian Sultan.
  • He successfully defended Delhi’s throne from Yeldoz, Qubacha raids, and Mongol invasions.
  • He strengthened his dominance over them by destroying the northern Rajput forces.
  • He produced coinage in his honor, made Delhi a splendid capital, and made his dominion hereditary.
  • He built a lot of mosques in Delhi and was a patron of the arts and architecture.

Question: Which of the following is essential to form haemoglobin in blood?
Solution:
Correct Answer Iron
Key Points Explanation:
  • Haemoglobin is a protein in your red blood cells that carries oxygen to your body's organs and tissues and transports carbon dioxide from your organs and tissues back to your lungs.
  • Haemoglobin is essential for transferring oxygen in your blood from the lungs to the tissues.
  • About 70 percent of your body's iron is found in the red blood cells of your blood called haemoglobin and in muscle cells called myoglobin.
  • Iron is the essential element of Hemoglobin.
  • Iron-deficient anaemia is a type of anaemia.
  • Red blood cells carry a biomolecule known as Hemoglobin.
  • The haemoglobin is responsible for binding oxygen molecule to itself and carrying it around the various human organs through the bloodstream.
  • Iron is the central atom in the biomolecule haemoglobin. The low concentration of iron affects the function of the bloodstream significantly to assure the availability of oxygen.
  • Therefore, anaemic patients are deficient in iron.

Important Points:
  • If a haemoglobin test reveals that your haemoglobin level is lower than normal, it means you have a low red blood cell count (Anemia).
  • Haemoglobin electrophoresis measures haemoglobin levels and looks for abnormal types of haemoglobin.
  • It's most often used to help diagnose anaemia, sickle cell disease, and other haemoglobin disorders.
  • The normal range for haemoglobin is: For men, 13.5 to 17.5 grams per deciliter. For women, 12.0 to 15.5 grams per deciliter.
  • Haemoglobin is produced in bone marrow by erythrocytes and is circulated with them until their destruction.
  • It is then broken down in the spleen, and some of its components, such as iron, are recycled to the bone marrow.

Question: Which of the following can degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances?
Solution:
The correct answer is Fungal enzymes
Key Points:
  • Bacterial and fungal enzymes degrade detritus into simpler inorganic substances. This process is called as catabolism.
  • The word catabolism is from New Latin, which got the roots from Greek: κάτω Kato, "downward" and βάλλειν ballein, "to throw".
  • It breaks down large molecules like polysaccharides, lipids, etc. into smaller units like monosaccharides, fatty acids, nucleotides, etc.
  • It is the breaking-down aspect of metabolism.
  • Cells use the monomers released from breaking down polymers to either construct new polymer molecules or degrade them into simple waste products like lactic acid, carbon dioxide, acetic acid, urea, and ammonia, releasing energy.
  • The creation of these wastes is usually an oxidation process involving a release of chemical-free energy. Of this, some are lost as heat, and the rest results in the formation of adenosine triphosphate (ATP).​
Additional Information:
  1. Catabolism is a metabolic process in which complex molecules are broken down into simpler ones with the release of energy. In the context of the given statement, bacterial and fungal enzymes break down the complex detritus into simpler inorganic substances such as carbon dioxide, water, and mineral ions. This breakdown process releases energy that can be used by the decomposers or other organisms in the ecosystem.
  2. Fragmentation: Detritivores (e.g., earthworms) break down detritus into smaller particles. This process is called fragmentation.
  3. Leaching: By the process of leaching, water-soluble inorganic nutrients go down into the soil horizon and get precipitated as unavailable salts.
  4. Decomposition: It is the process of breaking down a substance into its constituent parts. Decomposition of dead organic matter occurs in nature and it is also called decay or putrefaction.​

Question: Which group of animals are named because of their spiny skin and have a peculiar water-driven tube system that they use for moving around?
Solution:
The correct answer is Echinodermata.
Key Points
  • Invertebrates with pentaradial symmetry, spiny skin, a water circulatory system, and a simple nervous system are known as echinoderms.
  • There are around 7,000 extant species in this phylum.
  • Echinodermata are only found in the sea.
  • Echinoderms include sea stars, sea cucumbers, sea urchins, sand dollars, and brittle stars.
  • Echinoderms feature a calcareous endoskeleton with pentaradial symmetry and pigment cells that give them a wide spectrum of hues, as well as cells that contain poisons.
  • Water circulates through an echinoderm's water vascular system, which is made up of a central ring of canals that extends along each arm for gaseous exchange and nutrition.
  • Echinoderms have two sexes that release their eggs and sperm into the water, where the sperm fertilizes the eggs.ও
  • Echinoderms have the ability to reproduce asexually through regeneration.
  • The neurological system of echinoderms is exceedingly simple, consisting of a nerve ring in the center and five radial nerves radiating outward along the arms; there is no brain.​
Additional Information
  • Phylum Annelida:
    • Phylum Annelida contains the class Polychaeta (the polychaetes) and the class Oligochaeta (the earthworms, leeches, and their relatives).
    • These species can be found in a variety of settings, including marine, terrestrial, and freshwater, but the presence of water or humidity is essential for their survival, especially in terrestrial habitats.
    • This phylum's animals form parasitic and commensal symbioses with other species in their environment.
    • Because of its important property of metamerism, or real segmentation, annelids are commonly referred to as "segmented worms" throughout embryonic stages.
  • Phylum Arthropoda:
    • It includes animals that have been successful in colonizing terrestrial, aquatic, and aerial habitats.
    • Arthropods have jointed legs and a chitin exoskeleton.
    • Arthropods have a segmented body plan that contains fused segments divided into regions called tagma.
    • Arthropods have an open circulatory system and can breathe through their book gills, book lungs, or tracheal tubes.
  • Phylum Mollusca:
    • Phylum Mollusca is the predominant phylum in marine environments.
    • Mollusks have a soft body with a muscular foot, a visceral mass of internal organs, and a mantle, among other features.
    • The muscular foot of a mollusk is utilized for mobility and anchoring, and it comes in a variety of shapes and functions, as well as the ability to extend and retract.
    • The digestive, nervous, excretory, reproductive, and respiratory systems are all part of the mollusk's visceral mass.
    • Most mollusks have a radula, which looks like a tongue but has teeth-like projections for shredding or scraping food.

Question: Some cookies are automatically recreated after a user has deleted them. These are called _______ cookies.
Solution:
The correct option is 2) zombie.
Explanation:
  • Cookies are small text files that websites store on a user's computer or device when they visit the site.
  • Cookies can be used for a variety of purposes, such as remembering a user's preferences or login information.
  • However, some cookies can also be used to track a user's activity across multiple websites, which can raise privacy concerns.
Zombie
  • Zombie cookies, also known as "evercookies," are a type of persistent cookie that are difficult to remove.
  • Zombie cookies can be used to track a user's activity even if they delete their cookies or use private browsing mode.
  • The cookies that are automatically recreated after a user has deleted them are called "zombie cookies" or "evercookies".
Additional Information
Persistent
  • Persistent cookies are cookies that remain on a user's computer or device even after they close their browser.
  • These cookies can be used to remember a user's preferences or login information the next time they visit the website.
Session
  • Session cookies are cookies that are deleted when a user closes their browser.
  • These cookies are often used to keep track of a user's activity during a single browsing session, such as adding items to a shopping cart.
Third-party
  • Third-party cookies are cookies that are set by a domain other than the one the user is visiting.
  • For example, if a user visits a website and that website has embedded content from a third-party domain,
  • such as an advertisement or a social media plugin, the third-party domain may set a cookie on the user's computer.
  • This can allow the third-party domain to track the user's activity across multiple websites.

Question: Which among the following devices is also known as Visual Display Unit (VDU)?
Solution:
Virtual Display Unit (VDU)
  • It is also called or synonymously used with "monitor" which is an output device of the computer.
  • It consists of millions of tiny light particles called pixels, which are arranged in vertical and horizontal lines to form the image.
  • VDU or monitor displays entered text or images or graphics whenever the user enters it using any input devices.
  • VDU is the CRT type monitor with the main part being the Cathode Ray Tube, commonly called a picture tube.
  • CRT technology provides a cheap and good color output.
  • Types of Visual Display Units:
    • Liquid Crystal Displays.
    • LCD with LED Backlight.
    • Cathode Ray Tube.
    • Plasma.
    • LED

Question: In web browser, which of the following is responsible for displaying the web pages?
Solution:
The correct answer option 2) Rendering engine.
  • The rendering engine is responsible for displaying web pages in a web browser.
  • It is the component of the browser that takes the HTML, CSS, and JavaScript code of a web page and converts it into a visual representation that can be displayed on the screen.
Additional Information
  • Server: The server is responsible for hosting and serving web pages to the browser. When a user requests a web page, the browser sends a request to the server, which then responds with the requested page. The server may also handle other tasks such as processing form data or storing user information.
  • Page engine: There is no such component called Page engine in a web browser. It might refer to a software that helps to create or edit web pages.
  • Search Engine: A search engine is a software system that is used to search for information on the World Wide Web. It allows users to enter keywords or phrases related to their query and returns a list of relevant web pages or resources. Popular search engines include Google, Bing, Yahoo, and DuckDuckGo. Search engines are not responsible for displaying web pages in a web browser.

Question: Which among the following ports is also known as Line Printer Port?
Solution:
Line Printer Port
  • The port that is also known as Line Printer Port is the Parallel port.
  • This port is used to connect a computer to a parallel printer, which prints data one line at a time.
  • It is called a "line printer port" because parallel printers are often referred to as line printers due to the way they print data.
  • Parallel ports were common on older computers, but they have largely been replaced by USB ports for printer connectivity.
Hence, the correct answer is option 1.

Question: _______viruses are embedded in a system's memory so it can be reactivated if the original virus is deleted.
Solution:
The correct answer is Resident.
Key Points
  • A computer virus is a type of malevolent code or program written to alter the way a computer operates and is designed to spread from one computer to another.
  • A virus is corporate by inserting or attaching itself to a lawful program or document that supports macros in order to execute its code.
  • In the procedure, a virus has the prospective to cause unannounced or damaging effects, such as harming the system software by corrupting or destroying data.
  • Common types of Computer Viruses are:
    • File Infecting Virus
    • Macro Virus
    • Trojan Horse
    • Browser Hijacker
    • Web Scripting Virus
    • Boot Sector Virus
    • Polymorphic Virus
    • Resident Virus
    • Multipartite Virus​​
Important Points
  • Resident Virus:
    • ​Resident Viruses is a permanent virus that stays in the RAM memory and could cause interruption of the operations that the system has executed.
    • This leads to corrupt files and programs.
    • Examples are CMJ, Mr Klunky, Randex, and Meve.
  • ​Trojan Horse:
    • ​A Trojan horse is a hidden piece of code. Viruses enter a system secretly where the Trojan horse enters by deceiving a user.
    • A user allows or invites a Trojan into the system, believing in it, but actually, the Trojan horse contains some malicious code to perform some malicious activity.
    • Before a Trojan can attack, it must find a way to entice the victim to copy, download, and run it.
    • Since few people would knowingly run a malicious program, Trojan must disguise themselves as other programs that the victim believes to be harmless (such as games, utilities, or popular applications).
  • File Infector:
    • ​File infector virus is also known as a parasitic virus that usually infects memory and executable files.
  • Multipartite:​
    • This virus can attack both the boot sector and executable files of an infected computer.
    • When the virus attaches to the boot sector, it will in turn affect the system files.
    • When the virus attaches to the files, it will, in turn, infect the boot sector.

Question: Which among the following statements is incorrect about secondary memory?
OP1: It is known as the backup memory.
OP2: Data is permanently stored even if power is switched OFF.
OP3: Computer may run without the secondary memory.
Solution:
Correct Answer: It is a volatile memory.
  • Secondary memory is also known as auxiliary memory or external memory.
  • It is a type of computer memory that is used for long-term storage of data and programs, and it is not directly accessible to the CPU.
  • Secondary memory is non-volatile, which means that data stored on it is not lost when the power is switched off.
  • It is used for tasks such as storing operating systems, software applications, documents, media files, and other types of data that need to be accessed frequently but do not need to be kept in the primary memory (RAM) of the computer.
Additional Information
  • It is known as the backup memory: This statement is correct. Secondary memory is often used as a backup for data that is stored in primary memory (RAM).
  • This is because the data stored in RAM is volatile and can be lost if the power is turned off or if there is a system crash.
  • By contrast, data stored in secondary memory is non-volatile and can be retrieved even if the computer shuts down unexpectedly.
  • Data is permanently stored even if power is switched OFF: This statement is correct.
  • As mentioned earlier, secondary memory is non-volatile, which means that it retains data even when the power is switched off.
  • This is in contrast to primary memory (RAM), which is volatile and loses its contents when the power is turned off.
  • Computer may run without the secondary memory: This statement is also correct.
  • While secondary memory is an important component of a computer system, a computer can still run without it.
  • However, the absence of secondary memory will limit the amount of data and programs that the computer can store and access.
  • The computer will have to rely solely on its primary memory (RAM), which is usually much smaller in capacity than secondary memory.

Question: ______memory is sometimes used to increase the speed of processing by making current programs and data available to the CPU at a rapid rate.
Solution:
Cache Memory:
  • It is an extremely fast memory type that acts as a buffer between RAM and the CPU.
  • It holds frequently requested data and instructions so that they are immediately available to the CPU when needed.
  • It is a memory unit placed between the CPU and main memory M and is used to store instructions, data, or both.
  • It is used to reduce the average time to access data from the Main memory.
  • Cache memory is sometimes used to increase the speed of processing by making current programs and data available to the CPU at a rapid rate.

Which of the following statement(s) about Quick Access Toolbar in MS-Word 2010 is/are incorrect?

Q: The Quick Access Toolbar has Cut, Undo, and Redo buttons by default.

Question: _______ is the oldest type of Central Processing Unit (CPU).
Solution:
Single Core is the oldest type of Central Processing Unit (CPU).
  • A CPU is the primary component of a computer system that carries out instructions of a computer program.
  • The core is the part of the CPU that performs the arithmetic and logical operations necessary for the program's execution.
  • Single-core processors contain only one core and are capable of processing one set of instructions at a time.
  • They were the first type of CPU developed and were widely used until the early 2000s.
Additional Information
  • Dual Core: Dual-core processors contain two cores and are capable of processing two sets of instructions simultaneously, providing better performance than single-core processors.
  • They are still widely used in modern computers, particularly in laptops and desktops designed for general use.
  • Triple Core: Triple-core processors contain three cores and are capable of processing three sets of instructions simultaneously, providing even better performance than dual-core processors.
  • However, triple-core processors are relatively uncommon, and are not as widely used as dual-core or quad-core processors.
  • Quad Core: Quad-core processors contain four cores and are capable of processing four sets of instructions simultaneously, providing even better performance than dual-core and triple-core processors.
  • They are widely used in modern computers, particularly in high-end desktops and servers that require powerful processing capabilities.

Question: Which of the following is Math and trigonometric functions available in MS-Excel 365?
Solution:
The Math and Trigonometric functions available in MS-Excel 365 include:
  • ABS function: Returns the absolute value of a number.
  • Trigonometric functions: These include SIN, COS, TAN, ASIN, ACOS, and ATAN, which are used to calculate the sine, cosine, tangent, arcsine, arccosine, and arctangent of an angle.
  • LOG function: Returns the natural logarithm of a number.
  • EXP function: Returns e raised to the power of a given number.
  • SQRT function: Returns the square root of a number.
  • RAND function: Returns a random number between 0 and 1.
  • INT function: Rounds a number down to the nearest integer.
  • ROUND function: Rounds a number to a specified number of decimal places.
  • CEILING and FLOOR functions: Round numbers up or down to the nearest integer or multiple of a given value.
  • POWER function: Raises a number to a specified power.
  • MOD function: Returns the remainder when one number is divided by another.
  • SUM, AVERAGE, MAX, and MIN functions: These are basic statistical functions used to calculate the sum, average, maximum, and minimum of a range of numbers.
Note: The text function and logical function are not considered Math and Trigonometric functions, but rather fall under the categories of Text and Logical functions, respectively. Financial functions are also not classified as Math and Trigonometric functions, but rather as Financial functions.
Hence, the correct answer is option 2.

Question: Which among the following generations of computer used the technology of transistors for the first time?
Solution:
The correct answer is the Second generation of computers used the technology of transistors for the first time.
  • The Second generation of computers (1956-1963) used transistors instead of vacuum tubes, which were used in the first generation of computers.
  • Transistors were smaller, faster, and more reliable than vacuum tubes, and they consumed less power.
  • The development of transistors was a major breakthrough in computer technology, as it allowed for the creation of smaller, faster, and more reliable computers.
  • The second generation of computers also saw the introduction of magnetic core memory, which was faster and more reliable than the drum memory used in the first generation of computers.
Additional Information
  • Third Generation: The third generation of computers (1964-1971) saw the introduction of integrated circuits, which were smaller and more reliable than transistors. Integrated circuits allowed for the creation of even smaller and faster computers, and they paved the way for the development of microprocessors.
  • First Generation: The first generation of computers (1940s-1950s) used vacuum tubes as the primary electronic component. Vacuum tubes were large, fragile, and consumed a lot of power, and they were prone to failure. The first generation of computers were huge, expensive, and used mainly for scientific and military applications.
  • Fourth Generation: The fourth generation of computers (1971-1989) saw the introduction of microprocessors, which were integrated circuits that contained all the components of a computer's central processing unit (CPU) on a single chip. Microprocessors were smaller, faster, and more energy-efficient than the previous generation of computers, and they led to the development of personal computers (PCs). The fourth generation of computers also saw the development of the graphical user interface (GUI) and the mouse, which made computers more user-friendly and accessible to non-technical users.

Question: Which of the following option can be pressed to create a new email message in Gmail?
Solution:
The correct option that can be pressed to create a new email message in Gmail is: Compose
  • In Gmail, Compose is the button that can be clicked or the key that can be pressed to start creating a new email message.
  • It is usually located in the upper left-hand corner of the Gmail window, and it is represented by a red-colored "Compose" icon.
Additional Information
  • Settings, Outbound, and Drafts are also buttons in Gmail, but they are not used to create a new email message.
  • Instead, they are used for other functions in Gmail.
  • Settings: This button is used to access the settings menu in Gmail, where users can customize their Gmail account and adjust various settings such as filters, themes, and forwarding options.
  • Outbound: There is no button called "Outbound" in Gmail. It might refer to the "Sent" folder, where users can view their previously sent emails.
  • Drafts: This button is used to access the Drafts folder in Gmail, where users can find emails that they have started composing but have not yet sent.
  • Users can save a message as a draft and return to it later to finish composing it and send it.

Question: Each cell in the worksheet of MS-Excel 365 is identified by a cell _______.
Solution:
Each cell in the worksheet of MS-Excel 365 is identified by a cell reference.
  • Cell reference is a unique identifier for each cell in a worksheet, consisting of a column letter followed by a row number.
  • For example, the reference for the cell in the first column and the first row is A1.
  • Cell references are used in Excel formulas and functions to calculate and manipulate data in the worksheet.
  • They can also be used to create links between cells in different worksheets or workbooks, allowing users to reference data across multiple sheets or files.
Additional Information
  • Color: Color is a visual property that can be applied to cells in MS-Excel 365. Users can change the background color or font color of a cell to make it stand out or to make it easier to read. This can be done through the "Fill Color" or "Font Color" options in the "Home" tab of the Excel ribbon.
  • Size: Size refers to the dimensions of a cell in MS-Excel 365. Users can adjust the width and height of a cell to make it larger or smaller, depending on their needs. This can be done by dragging the column or row headers to the desired size or by using the "Format Cells" dialog box in the "Home" tab of the Excel ribbon.
  • Rounding: Rounding is a mathematical function that can be applied to numbers in MS-Excel 365. Users can round numbers to a specified number of decimal places or to the nearest whole number, depending on their needs. This can be done through the "Number" format options in the "Home" tab of the Excel ribbon.

Question: _______ is a type of dedicated file storage device that provides local-area network (LAN) users with centralized, consolidated disk storage through a standard Ethernet connection.
Solution:
The correct answer is option 4) Network Attached Storage (NAS).
  • NAS is a type of dedicated file storage device that provides local-area network (LAN) users with centralized, consolidated disk storage through a standard Ethernet connection.
  • It is designed to be easy to use, and it offers a cost-effective way to store and share files across a network.
  • Unlike solid-state drives (SSDs), USB hard drives, and USB sticks, which are typically used for portable storage, NAS is a network-based storage solution that can be accessed by multiple users simultaneously.
Additional Information
  • Solid-State Drive (SSD): SSDs are storage devices that use solid-state flash memory to store data. They are faster, more reliable, and more energy-efficient than traditional hard disk drives (HDDs), and they are often used as the primary storage device in desktop and laptop computers. SSDs come in various form factors, including the standard 2.5-inch drive size for desktop and laptop computers, and the smaller M.2 form factor used in ultrabooks and tablets.
  • USB Hard Drives: USB hard drives are portable storage devices that use a USB interface to connect to a computer or other device. They typically have a larger storage capacity than USB sticks and are often used to store large files, such as videos and photos. USB hard drives come in various sizes and form factors, ranging from small, pocket-sized drives to larger, desktop-sized drives.
  • USB Sticks: USB sticks, also known as USB flash drives or thumb drives, are small, portable storage devices that use a USB interface to connect to a computer or other device. They are typically used to store and transfer small files, such as documents, photos, and music. USB sticks come in various sizes and capacities, ranging from a few megabytes to several gigabytes

Question: Which among the following statements is incorrect?
OP1: The right window of Windows Explorer is called Navigation Pane.
OP2: From the Navigation pane, you can view your computer's file and folder structure and access files and folders.
OP3: In the Navigation Pane, there is a Quick Access area.
OP4: Navigation Pane is to enable easier navigation through Windows Explorer.
Solution:
Statement 1 is incorrect.
  • The right window of Windows Explorer is not called Navigation Pane.
  • The right window is called the Content Pane, and it displays the contents of the folder or file selected in the Navigation Pane.
  • The Navigation Pane is located on the left side of the Windows Explorer window, and it displays the file and folder structure of the computer.
Additional Information
  • From the Navigation pane, you can view your computer's file and folder structure and access files and folders: This statement is correct. The Navigation Pane in Windows Explorer allows you to navigate through the file and folder structure of your computer, and access files and folders.
  • In the Navigation Pane, there is a Quick Access area: This statement is correct. In the Navigation Pane, there is a Quick Access area that provides quick access to frequently used folders and files.
  • Navigation Pane is to enable easier navigation through Windows Explorer: This statement is correct. The Navigation Pane in Windows Explorer is designed to make it easier to navigate through the file and folder structure of your computer, and to access files and folders quickly and easily

Question: Once_______ has infected a substantial number of computer systems, it generates revenue either by displaying advertisements or using a "pay per click" mechanism to charge its clients against the number of clicks on their displayed ads.
Solution:
Adware:
  • Adware is software that displays unwanted and aggressive advertising to end-users (for example, pop-up adverts).
  • Malvertising is the use of legal advertisements to distribute malware to end-user PCs.
  • Adware earns cash for its creator by showing internet adverts in the software's user interface or on a screen that appears in the user's face during the installation process.
  • Hence the correct answer is adware.
Additional Information
  • A Trojan virus, or Trojan, is a type of malicious software that disguises itself as legitimate software to trick users into installing it. Once installed, it can perform harmful actions such as stealing data, damaging system files, creating backdoors for remote control, and installing more malware. Trojans are not self-replicating; they need to be manually installed by the user. To stay protected, maintain updated software, avoid suspicious downloads, and use reliable antivirus tools regularly.
  • The worm has the ability to replicate itself without the input of the end-user and may swiftly infect huge networks by migrating from one system to another.
  • Spyware snoops on unsuspecting end users, gathering credentials and passwords, browser history, and other information.

Question: Which among the following keyboard shortcuts is used to bookmark the current webpage on the web browser?
Solution:
The keyboard shortcut used to bookmark the current webpage on a web browser is:
4) Ctrl + D
  • Pressing "Ctrl + D" simultaneously on Windows or Linux or "Command + D" on a Mac will bring up a prompt to add the current webpage to the bookmarks or favorites list in the web browser.
  • This shortcut is a quick and convenient way to save a webpage for future reference or easy access.
Additional Information
  • Ctrl + N: This keyboard shortcut is used to open a new window in most web browsers. It is also used to open a new document or window in some applications. Pressing "Ctrl + N" simultaneously on Windows or Linux or "Command + N" on a Mac will open a new window in the web browser, allowing you to browse to a new webpage or have multiple webpages open at once.
  • Ctrl + I: This keyboard shortcut is used to open the bookmarks or favorites manager in most web browsers. It is also used to italicize text in some applications. Pressing "Ctrl + I" simultaneously on Windows or Linux or "Command + I" on a Mac will open the bookmarks or favorites manager in the web browser, allowing you to organize or access your saved bookmarks or favorites.
  • Ctrl + B: This keyboard shortcut is used to toggle the bookmarks or favorites bar on and off in most web browsers. It is also used to bold text in some applications. Pressing "Ctrl + B" simultaneously on Windows or Linux or "Command + B" on a Mac will toggle the bookmarks or favorites bar on and off in the web browser, allowing you to easily access your saved bookmarks or favorites.

Question: _______ is also known as protocol convertor.

The correct answer is 4
Key Points
  • The gateway may be a single component of a networking hardware system applied in the field of telecommunication for the interaction of devices, that enable the info flow from one discrete network to others.
  • They act as routers or switches that are capable of interacting with multiple networks and may work on seven layers of the OSI model.
  • They can be unidirectional (allowing data to flow in only one direction) or bidirectional (allowing data to flow both in and out of a network). Hence statement 2 is not correct.

  • Node:

Question: _______ are rules that exist at several levels in a telecommunication connection.
Solution:
• Protocol are rules that exist at several levels in a telecommunication connection.
  • Protocols are a set of rules and standards that govern how data is transmitted between devices in a network.
  • They define the format, timing, sequencing, and error checking of data transmitted over a network, and enable devices from different manufacturers to communicate with each other. Examples of common protocols include TCP/IP, HTTP, FTP, SMTP, and DNS.
Additional Information
  • Bandwidth: Bandwidth refers to the amount of data that can be transmitted over a communication channel in a given amount of time.
  • It is typically measured in bits per second (bps) or bytes per second (Bps).
  • Bandwidth is an important factor in determining the speed and capacity of a network, and it is affected by factors such as the type of transmission medium, the number of users on the network, and the quality of the signal.
  • Network Surface Unit: It's possible that you meant "Network Interface Unit" or "Network Interface Card" (NIC), which is a hardware component that allows a device to connect to a network.
  • A NIC typically provides a physical interface (such as an Ethernet port) for connecting to the network, as well as the necessary drivers and software for controlling the connection.
  • Domain Name: A domain name is a unique identifier for a website or other internet resource.
  • It typically consists of two parts: a top-level domain (TLD), such as .com, .org, or .edu, and a second-level domain (SLD), which is the specific name chosen by the owner of the domain.
  • Domain names are used to make it easier for users to find and access websites, and they are managed by domain name registrars and domain name system (DNS) servers.

Question: Which of the following font effects is not available in the MS-Word 2010 font dialog box?
Solution:
The font effect that is not available in the MS-Word 2010 font dialog box is "Equalize Character Height".
  • Equalize Character Height: This option is not available in the MS-Word 2010 font dialog box, but in general, it would be used to adjust the size of characters so that they are all the same height.
  • This can be useful for creating a consistent look across text that uses different fonts or styles.
  • However, as noted, this option is not available in MS-Word 2010, so it cannot be used in that program.
Additional Information
  • Superscript: This option is used to format text so that it appears above the regular text line and slightly smaller.
  • It is commonly used for mathematical and scientific formulas, as well as for footnotes.
  • Small Caps: This option formats the selected text in a way that makes all the letters uppercase, but with the lowercase letters being smaller than the uppercase letters.
  • This option is useful for creating headings and titles that stand out without being too obtrusive.
  • Double Strikethrough: This option adds a double line through the selected text, creating a strikethrough effect that is thicker than the single strikethrough option.
  • It is often used to indicate that text has been completely deleted or to emphasize that something is not applicable.
